cards.back:
A visual tool for Boolean function minimization.

Arranges truth table values in a 2D grid using Gray code ordering so that adjacent cells differ by exactly one variable.

This makes simplification visible as pattern matching!

00 → 01 → 11 → 10

NOT binary order (00, 01, 10, 11)!

Key property: Each consecutive pair differs by exactly ONE bit.

This is essential for K-map adjacency.

Two cells are adjacent if they differ by exactly ONE variable.

Includes wrap-around:
• Left edge ↔ Right edge
• Top edge ↔ Bottom edge

Diagonal cells are NOT adjacent!

Adjacency theorem:
XY + X̄Y = Y

When two adjacent cells both have 1:
• They share (n-1) variables
• The one differing variable is eliminated

Grouping adjacent 1s = eliminating variables!

2 variables: 2×2 (4 cells)
3 variables: 2×4 (8 cells)
4 variables: 4×4 (16 cells)
5 variables: Two 4×4 maps (32 cells)

Beyond 5-6 variables: Use Quine-McCluskey

Groups must contain 2^n cells:

✓ 1, 2, 4, 8, 16...
✗ 3, 5, 6, 7, 9...

Groups must also be RECTANGULAR (including wrap-around rectangles).

For minterm m_i:

1. Convert i to binary
2. Split bits: first half → row, second half → column
3. Find position using Gray code labels

Example: m5 = 0101
→ AB=01, CD=01
→ Row 01, Column 01

For n-variable K-map:

| Group Size | Variables Eliminated |
|------------|---------------------|
| 1 | 0 |
| 2 | 1 |
| 4 | 2 |
| 8 | 3 |
| 2^k | k |

Bigger groups = simpler terms!

K-map wraps around like a torus:

• Column 00 ↔ Column 10
• Row 00 ↔ Row 10
• Four corners are mutually adjacent!

Don't forget these when grouping!
